data.title: OTD in Music History: Legendary composer, pianist, and conductor Igor Stravinsky (1882 - 1971) is born in a small town just outside of...
data.meta_description:
243 likes, 9 comments - music_history_in_photos on June 17, 2024: "OTD in Music History: Legendary composer, pianist, and conductor Igor Stravinsky (1882 - 1971) is born in a small town just outside of Saint Petersburg.

Universally acclaimed as one of the greatest composers of the 20th Century, Stravinsky’s artistic career — much like that of his close friend and exact contemporary, Pablo Picasso (1881 - 1973) — was perhaps most notable for its dizzying stylistic diversity.

Stravinsky first shot to fame with three momentous ballets on Russian themes that were commissioned by Sergei Diaghilev (1872 - 1929) and premiered by Diaghilev’s famous “Ballets Russes”: “The Firebird” (1910), “Petrushka” (1911), and “The Rite of Spring” (1913).

This so-called “Russian period” — which also featured “L’Histoire du soldat” (1918) and “Les Noces” (1923) — was then followed by a long period during which Stravinsky explored “neoclassicism” in works that deployed highly traditional musical forms to highly modernist ends.

After the death of serialist pioneer Arnold Schoenberg (1874 - 1951), Stravinsky (perhaps not coincidentally) finally began to explore some of the serial procedures which he had previously made a point of studiously avoiding.

Nevertheless, just like Picasso, Stravinsky’s overpowering artistic personality invariably emerges in the distinctive traits which characterize his work regardless across all of these periods: a driving, spiky, and frequently irregular rhythmic energy; the careful and meticulous construction of extended melodic ideas out of just a few short two- or three-note cells; and a remarkable clarity and logic in form.

PICTURED: A first edition copy of Stravinsky’s (ghostwritten) 1936 English-language autobiography, which was simply entitled, “Stravinsky: An Autobiography.”

This was actually just a translation of the (ghostwritten) French-language autobiography which had been published in Paris the year before, under a slightly more creative title: “Chroniques de ma vie.”

Stravinsky signed this copy.".
